blogs.title: Boudhanath Stupa
blogs.author: Levinly Travel
blogs.excerpt: A comprehensive guide to Boudhanath Stupa, one of Nepal's most important Buddhist sites.

content.introduction: Boudhanath Stupa is situated at Boudha, a culturally diverse neighbourhood in the northeastern part of Kathmandu, Nepal. It is located about 7 kilometres northeast of Thamel, the city's popular tourist hub. One of the most renowned and spiritually charged places in Nepal, Boudhanath Stupa rises gracefully above the Kathmandu Valley as a sign of wisdom, compassion, and the order of the universe. Having outstanding universal value as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, it is a sacred destination, meditation, and cultural diversity, especially for practitioners of Tibetan Buddhism.
content.heritage: The source of Boudhanath traces back to the 5th century CE, throughout Ucchavi time, although legends suggest the possibility of an even earlier foundation. According to the traditional story, the stupa was assigned by a humble woman named Ma Jhyalima, who put in a plea for land from the king to build a shrine for a Buddha's remains.

architecture.mandala: The stupa is formed in the shape of a giant mandala, symbolising the universe.
architecture.dome: The white dome symbolises the limitlessness of the universe and the clarity of thought.
architecture.spire: The golden steeple with 13 steps shows the progression of stages on the path to enlightenment.
architecture.eyes: The all-seeing eyes of Buddha watch over the four directions, representing wisdom and awareness.
architecture.nose: The nose-like symbol symbolises the Nepali number 1 (unity) and the path to enlightenment.
architecture.flags: Prayer flags carry mantras and blessings into the wind, amplifying prayers and intentions.

content.rituals: Daily, a large number of pilgrims and devotees come to perform kora—ritual circumambulation (pradakshina) of the stupa in a clockwise direction. The rhythmic rotation of the prayer wheels, the chanting of mantras (mainly 'Om Mani Padme Hum'), and the offering of butter lamps and incense are central to the spiritual ambience.

festivals.name: Losar (Tibetan New Year)
festivals.description: Defined by traditional dances, music, butter sculptures, and public blessings.

festivals.name: Buddha Jayanti (Vaisakha)
festivals.description: Glory the birth, enlightenment, and death of Lord Buddha.

festivals.name: Lhabab Duchen
festivals.description: Celebrates the Buddha's descent from Tushita heaven.

practical.dressCode: Wear clothing that covers your shoulders, chest, and knees. Avoid sleeveless tops, short skirts, or overly tight or revealing outfits.
etiquette: Always walk clockwise around the stupa.
Refrain from loud conversations, smoking, or public displays of affection.
Remove shoes before entering monastery interiors.

attractions: Monasteries: Shacheon Monastery, Ka-Nying Shendrub Ling, Thangtu Tashi Yangtse
Souvenir Shops: Prayer flags, singing bowls, thangka paintings
Kapan Monastery: A 15-minute drive for meditation retreats
